title: Lens images - objects at 1-half f and 3-halves f

content.question: An object can be placed on the principal axis of a lens at either of two points, Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>P</mtext></math> or Point <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Q</mtext></math>, as shown in the figure. The lens is convex with a focal length equal to <math alttext="lowercase f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math>. Points <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>P</mtext></math>, <math alttext="uppercase F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi></math>, and <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Q</mtext></math> are located at distances of <math alttext="three halves lowercase f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>f</mi></math>, <math alttext="lowercase f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math>, and <math alttext="one half lowercase f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>f</mi></math>, respectively, from the center of the lens. Additionally, two principal rays are indicated for when the object is at Point <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Q</mtext></math>. How does the magnitude of the height of the image formed by the lens compare when the object is at Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>P</mtext></math> versus when the object is at Point <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Q</mtext></math>? What evidence or reasoning helps support the claim?

choices.label: It is greater when the object is at Point <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Q</mtext></math>. The reciprocal of the object-lens distance <math alttext="open parenthesis, the fraction 1 over s sub o, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>o</mi></msub></mfrac><mo>)</mo></math> is greater the closer the object is to the lens.

It is greater when the object is at Point <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Q</mtext></math>. The principal ray passing through the center of the lens makes a greater angle from the principal axis when the object is at Point <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Q</mtext></math>.
It is the same for both object locations. Magnification is a property of the lens and is independent of where an object is located.

It is the same for both object locations. The principal ray originating from Point <math alttext="uppercase F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi></math> reaches the lens at the same distance from the principal axis when the object is at either location.

content.answer: It is the same for both object locations. The principal ray originating from Point <math alttext="uppercase F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi></math> reaches the lens at the same distance from the principal axis when the object is at either location.
